citation.article-title: Amycolatopsis taiwanensis sp. nov., from soil
citation.source: International Journal of Systematic and Evolutionary Microbiology

p.s: Description of Amycolatopsis taiwanensis sp. nov.
Amycolatopsis taiwanensis (tai.wan.en′sis. N.L. fem. adj. taiwanensis of Taiwan, where the type strain was isolated).
Short spore chains are formed on substrate mycelia; spores are oval with a smooth surface and are non-motile.
The substrate mycelium is yellowish white to purple yellow.
Growth is good on most test media, but sporulation is very poor.
Good growth occurs between 20 and 40 °C; no growth occurs above 1 % NaCl.
Hydrolyses casein and aesculin and is positive for gelatin liquefaction.
Glucose, arabinose, cellulose and sucrose can be used as sole carbon sources for growth, but not fructose or salicin; use of rhamnose, inositol, raffinose, mannitol and xylose is questionable.
The cell-wall peptidoglycan contains meso-A2pm; arabinose, galactose, glucose and ribose are detected in whole-cell hydrolysates.
Major cellular fatty acids are iso-C16 : 0 (38.1 %) and C17 : 1 (25.4 %).
The G+C content of the DNA of the type strain is 68.9 mol%.
The type strain, 0345M-7T (=BCRC 16802T=KCTC 19116T), was isolated from a soil collected from Yilan county, Taiwan.
